name: Length scale factor in similar shapes 2

skills.name: Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the longer one
Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1
Understand that an enlargement of a shape does not change the size of angles

explanations.A: The scale factor is 17.5/5 = 3.5, so we multiply 2 by 3.5 to get 7cm.
explanations.B: I think you may have estimated the scale factor to be about 4. What is the exact number we need to multiply 5 by to get to 17.5?
explanations.C: I think you have added 12.5cm to the 2cm side, but this will not keep the sides in proportion. We need to find the scale factor by working out what number we need to multiply 5 by in order to get 17.5
explanations.D: I think you have correctly found the scale factor (3.5), but forgotten to work out the missing length. If all lengths are 3.5 times as big, what will the missing length be?

explanations.A: It looks like you have multiplied the lengths together. To find the scale factor, we are looking for the number we need to multiply the smaller length by to get the larger length. 8 x ? = 12
explanations.B: Almost! The scale factor is the number we have to multiply the smaller shape lengths by to get the larger shape lengths. 8 x ? = 12
explanations.C: You have found the difference between the side lengths, but that is not the scale factor. The scale factor is the number that we have to multiply the smaller shape lengths by to get the larger shape lengths. 8 x ? = 12
explanations.D: To calculate the scale factor, we need to know how many times longer the sides of the large shape are than the sides of the small shape. So we do 12 ÷ 8 = 1.5.

explanations.A: The two triangles are similar because the triangles have two pairs of angles that are equal (although one triangle has been rotated compared to the other). So we know that angle k must equal 60°. Alternatively, in the smaller triangle, we know that angles in a triangle add to 180°, so k = 180 − (75 ＋ 45) = 60°.
explanations.B: I think you have doubled the angle. Look at the other 2 angles in the smaller triangle. What do angles in a triangle add up to?
explanations.C: I think you have halved the angle because the side length has been halved. Look at the other 2 angles in the smaller triangle. What do angles in a triangle add up to?
explanations.D: Because the 2 angles either side of our given length are the same (45 and 75) then we have a pair of similar triangles. Which angle would correspond to 'k' on the larger triangle?

explanations.D: Because the 2 angles either side of our given length are the same (50 and 70) then we have a pair of similar triangles. Which angle would correspond to 'p' on the larger triangle?

explanations.A: The perimeter is the length all the way round the shape. If all the lengths making up the perimeter are doubled, the effect on the perimeter will also be to double it. To show this, let’s call the lengths of the sides on this shape a, b, c and d. On the new shape, the lengths will be 2a ＋ 2b ＋ 2c ＋ 2d = 2(a ＋ b ＋ c ＋ d) = 2 ✕ perimeter of original shape.
explanations.B: If we have doubled each side then we have multiplied each side by 2. Is this the same as adding 2 to our perimeter?
explanations.C: It looks like you might have tried to double the perimeter 4 times, once for each side. When we double one side, we don't double the whole perimeter. What effect would doubling all the sides have?
explanations.D: We do have enough information here, but it might help you to make up a number for the length of each side and see what happens to the perimeter when you double all of your numbers. Remember 'double' means 'multiply by 2'.

explanations.A: You might have tried to treble the perimeter 3 times, once for each side. When we treble one side, we don't treble the whole perimeter. What effect would trebling all the sides have?
explanations.B: If we have trebled each side then we have multiplied each side by 3. Is this the same as adding 3 to the perimeter?
explanations.C: The perimeter is the length all the way round the shape. If all the lengths making up the perimeter are trebled, the perimeter will also be trebled. If we call the lengths of the sides on this shape a, b and c, the lengths on the new shape will be 3a ＋ 3b ＋ 3c = 3(a ＋ b ＋ c) = 3 ✕ perimeter of original shape.
explanations.D: We do have enough information here, but it might help you to make up a number for the length of each side and see what happens to the perimeter when you treble all of your numbers. Remember that 'treble' means 'multiply by 3'.

explanations.A: You may have chosen to multiply as it has been enlarged (gets bigger). However 4 x 10 would give us 40. Are the lengths on shape Q 40 times bigger than the lengths on shape P?
explanations.B: You have worked out the difference between the 2 lengths. Instead, we are looking for the number which we need to multiply 4 by in order to get to 10.
explanations.C: Nearly! Your answer would be right if we were going from Shape Q to Shape P but we need to go the other way. 4 divided by 10 gives us 0.4. Is shape Q 0.4 times as big as shape P?
explanations.D: Take care to note which ‘way’ the enlargement works: the question states from shape P to shape Q, so we are being asked 4 ✕ ? = 10. To work out ?, the constant of proportionality, we need to use the inverse of ✕ 4. So we need 10 ÷ 4.
